section.title: Slow navigation to end or beginning of game
section.para: This happens while going forward or backward for a large number of moves in a game. Since Java offers no stream selectors for file streams, GoGui needs to use thread synchronization to read the output and error stream of the Go program for preserving the correct order of the received output in the GTP shell and for detecting timeouts. This synchronizationcan becomes slow if there are other CPU intensive background processes running on the computer. The problem can be avoided if the Go engine implements the gg-undo and gogui-play_sequence commands (see ), then a single command can replace up to several hundred play or undo commands.

section.title: Rendering errors in the GTP shell
section.para: Rendering errors in the GTP shell window occur, which disappear after manually resizing the window. This is probably a bug in the Java libraries. With Java 1.4.2 for Linux, this problem seems to have disappeared after introducing a workaround, which resets the window size after each text update. With other Java versions, or on other systems, the problem can still exist.

section.title: Standard error and output of the GTP engine are displayed in wrong order
section.para: Due to deficiencies in the Java library, it cannot be guaranteed that the standard error and standard output of the GTP engine are always displayed in the correct order in the GTP shell. Also, the GTP shell is not updated immediately during command sequences that the engine is supposed to perform quickly, like play commands, or while the engine is waiting for the next command. In cases where the order is critical for debugging purposes, it is better to invoke GoGui from a terminal with the -verbose option and watch the logging of the GTP streams in the terminal.

section.title: Out of memory error when loading large SGF trees
section.para:
Java uses a low maximum memory heap size by default. It can be increased by using the "-Xmx" option, for example for 512MB:
java -Xmx512M -jar gogui.jar
Don't use more memory than there is real memory on the machine, because using swap space will make the program unusable slow.

section.title: Wrong line numbers in SGF error messages
section.para: If reading an SGF file fails, the line numbers of the error messages are sometimes wrong. This is due to bugs in the Java class StreamTokenizer, which is used for parsing the SGF stream.
